question: Pregnant women should only practice Prāṇāyāma and Dhyān, as Mudrā, Bandha, and Āsana can be harmful to the child.
options: False, there are specific Mudrās, Bandhas, and Āsanas for the healthy development of the child
description: Certain asanas (e.g., Baddha Konasana, Vajrasana variations), mudras (e.g., Yoni Mudra), and breathing techniques (e.g., Anuloma-Viloma without retention) are safe and beneficial during pregnancy when guided properly.

question: Which āsana helps in improving balance?
description: Both Mayūrāsana (peacock pose) and Kukkuṭāsana (cock pose) demand strong core control and arm balance, thus improving balance and stability.

question: Which āsana is considered best for Diabetes?
description: Matsyendrāsana (spinal twist) stimulates pancreas; Mayūrāsana improves digestion and balances insulin secretion. Both are recommended for diabetes management.

question: Which practice is beneficial to get rid of enlargement of the glands?
description: HYP Ch2 - Verse 27: Enlargement of the glands and spleen, and all diseases arising from excess wind, bile and mucus are eliminated from the body through the practice of basti.

question: Which practice is beneficial to improve the executive functions of the brain?
What is the average number of breaths per minute?
description: The average number of breaths being 15 per minute means the brain is compressed and decompressed that many times. But in Kapalbhati we breath 50-100 times, stimulating the brain three to seven times more than normal per round. Kapalbhati also expels more carbon dioxide and other waste gases from the cells and lungs than normal breathing.

question: Which practice helps in stimulating the thyroid gland?
description: Ujjayi Pranayama creates a gentle throat friction, stimulating the thyroid gland and balancing metabolism.

question: Which Dhyana is considered best as per Gheranda Samhita?
description: Jyoti dhyana is one hundred times superior to sthoola dhyana and sukshma dhyana is one hundred thousand times superior to jyoti dhyana.

question: Sagarbha and Nigarbha are types of which pranayama?
description: Gheranda Samhita Ch5 Verse 47: Sahita Pranayama (with sound/mantra or without) is of two kinds: Sagarbha (with bija mantra) and Nigarbha (without mantra).

question: The Yoga structure given in Gheranda Samhita is referred as
description: Sage Gheranda calls his seven-limbed yoga Ghatastha Yoga, which means yoga based on the body. Ghata means body (śarīra) and also pot or pitcher. He compares the body to a clay pot made of matter, filled by God with senses, mind, knowledge, wisdom, and ego — this becomes our "pitcher." The seven limbs of Gheranda’s yoga are: 1. Shatkarma; 2.Asana; 3. Mudra – energy; 4. Pratyahara; 5. Pranayama; 6. Dhyana – meditation; 7. Samadhi

question: As per Gheranda Samhita Pratyahara gives
description: Āsanena bhaved dṛḍhatā → By practising āsanas, dṛḍhatā (firmness/strength) is attained. Mudrayā sthiratā → By practising mudrās, sthiratā (stability) is attained. Pratyāhāreṇa dhīratā → By practising pratyāhāra, dhīratā (patience/calmness) is attained. Prāṇāyāma l-lāghavam → By practising prāṇāyāma, lāghavam (lightness, removal of heaviness) is attained. Dhyānāt pratyakṣa ātmanaḥ → By practising dhyāna, pratyakṣa (direct realization of the Self) is attained. Samādhinā nirliptatā → By practising samādhi, nirliptatā (detachment, non-involvement) is attained.

question: Which asana is not part of Gheranda Samhita?
description: As per this text, these 32 asanas are sufficient to attain siddhi or perfection: 1. Siddhasana, 2. Padmasana, 3.  Bhadrasana, 4. Muktasana, 5. Vajrasana, 6. Swastikasana, 7. Simhasana, 8. Gomukhasana, 9. Veerasana, 10. Dhanurasana, 11. Mritasana (Shavasana), 12. Guptasana, 13. Matsyasana, 14. Matsyendrasana, 15. Gorakshasana, 16. Paschimottanasana, 17. Utkatasana, 18. Sankatasana, 19. Mayurasana, 20. Kukkutasana, 21. Koormasana, 22. Utthan koormasana, 23. Mandukasana, 24. Utthan mandukasana, 25. Vrikshasana, 26. Garudasana, 27. Vrishasana, 28. Shalabhasana, 29. Makarasana, 30. Ushtrasana, 31. Bhujangasana, 32. Yogasana

question: Which of this mudra is not part of Gheranda Samhita?
Which seasons are best to start the yoga practice?
As per Gherand Samhita, the highest type of Pranayama gives
As per Gheranda Samhita, the lowest type of Pranayama gives
Rasanand Samadhi can be achieved by
description: As per Gheranda Samhita, Shambhavi and bhramari, khechari and yoni mudras respectively accomplish the four states of dhyana, nada, rasananda and laya siddhi.

question: Which of the following is mentioned in Hatharatnavali?
description: Hatharatnavali by Srinivasa Yogi mentions Maha Yoga as one of the types.

question: How many asanas are mentioned in Hatharatnavali?
description: The Haṭharatnāvalī is a 17th-century Haṭhayoga text composed by Śrīnivāsa. Unlike Haṭhapradīpikā (15th c.) and Gheraṇḍa Saṁhitā (17th c.), this text is remarkable because it gives the largest list of 84 āsanas (citing the tradition that Śiva taught 8.4 million āsanas, of which 84 are the best).

question: Which karma is considered best by Srinivasa Yogi?
description: It is a special purification kriyā mentioned only in Haṭharatnāvalī. Described as a practice of rapid circular movement of the abdomen – like an advanced form of Nauli. Said to destroy all doṣas, awaken kuṇḍalinī, and make the body shine.

question: The practice that involves moving the head to the left and right while doing Pooraka and Rechaka is called
description: Hatharatnavali describes Mastakbhranti as head movements with breathing.

question: Which Kumbhaka is mentioned only in Hatharatnavali?
description: Hatharatnavali uniquely mentions Bhujangakarani Kumbhaka.

question: Manas and Kayik Niyamas are part of
description: Hatharatnavali describes mental (Manas) and bodily (Kayik) niyamas.

question: Most important asanas as per Hatha Ratnavali
description: All three asanas are core seated postures for meditation and pranayama.

question: How many Mudras are mentioned in Hatharatnavali?
When prana enters Susumna nadi, chitta becomes stable
description: According to Hatha Yoga Pradipika (4.4–4.6), when prana enters the Suṣumṇā nadi, the mind (chitta) becomes steady and thoughtless, leading to Manonmani Avastha (the state beyond the mind). This state is also called Unmani Avastha, Samadhi, or Raja Yoga in different texts, because all these indicate higher absorption of consciousness.

question: Not a type of Padmasana
description: The classical texts like Hatha Yoga Pradipika and Gheranda Samhita do not list Parivritta Padmasana as a traditional form, while the other three (Bandha, Samputita, Shuddha) are referenced.

question: Part of Yama as per HYP
description: Chapter 1, Verse 16: 10 Yamas according to HYP Ahimsa – Non-violence; Satya – Truthfulness; Asteya – Non-stealing; Brahmacharya – Celibacy / moderation in sexual energy; Kshama – Forgiveness / patience; Dhriti – Fortitude / steadfastness; Daya – Compassion; Arjava – Honesty / straightforwardness; Mitahara – Moderation in diet; Shaucha – Cleanliness / purity

question: Not part of Niyama as per HYP
description: 10 Niyamas according to HYP (Chapter 1, Verse 16): Tapas – Austerity, discipline; Santosha – Contentment; Astikya – Faith in higher reality (or scriptures) Dana – Charity, generosity; Ishwara Pujanam – Worship of God; Siddhanta Vakya Shravana – Study of scriptures / listening to spiritual teachings; Hrī – Modesty, humility; Mati – Right understanding, reflection; Japa – Repetition of mantra; Huta / Homa – Fire offerings, sacrifice

question: Part of Sadhaka Tattva
description: HYP 1.16 – Six Sādhaka Tattvas (success factors): 1. Utsāha – Enthusiasm; 2. Sāhasa – Courage; 3. Dhairya – Patience; 4. Tattva-jñāna – Knowledge of truth; 5. Nischaya – Determination; 6. Jana-sanga parityāga – Avoiding bad company

question: Part of Badhaka Tattva
description: HYP 1.15 – Six causes of failure (to be avoided): 1. Atyāhāra – Overeating; 2. Prayāsa – Overexertion; 3. Prajalpa – Useless talk; 4. Niyamāgraha – Mechanical observance (or neglect) of rules; 5. Jana-sanga – Too much socializing; 6. Laulya – Fickleness

question: Hri means
description: This is from the 10 Niyamas of Hatha Yoga Pradipika (HYP 1.18).  Hrī (ह्रीः) means modesty / humility / sense of shame in doing wrong.

question: Prajalpa means
description: This is from Hatha Yoga Pradipika 1.15, the six causes of failure in Yoga. Over-exertion(Prayāsa); Talkativeness (Prajalpa); Over-adhering to rules (Niyamāgraha); Perseverance (that is part of Sādhaka Tattva → Dhairya)

question: Panchadharana (as per GS) includes
description: Five concentration practices: parthivi (earth), ambhasi (water), agneyi (fire), vayviye (air) and akashi (space or ether)

question: How many types of Samadhi in GS?
description: 1. Bhakti Yoga; 2. Dhyana Yoga;  3. Laya Siddhi; 4. Manomoorchha; 5. Nada Yoga; 6. Rasananda

question: On average, humans breathe almost
description: Normal adult respiration ≈ 15 breaths/min × 60 × 24 ≈ 21600/day.

question: Respiration refers to
description: Respiration = physiological process + breathing movement.

question: Nadi is a complex mechanism that allows flow of
description: Nadis = subtle channels for pranic flow.

question: Nadis originate from
description: Nadis radiate from Brahma-sthan / Kanda sthana (spinal base).

question: As per Shiva Samhita, how many Nadis?
description: Nadi is a flow of energy. The Shiva Samhita says that altogether there are 350,000 nadis in the body, the Prapanchasara Tantra says 300,000 and the Goraksha Satarka says 72,000. There are thousands upon thousands of nadis within the superstructure of the gross body and they distribute consciousness and prana to every atom.

question: Nadi linked to Sympathetic NS
description: Ida Nadi – Cooling, lunar, left side, parasympathetic functions (rest–digest). Pingala Nadi – Heating, solar, right side, sympathetic functions (fight–flight). Sushumna Nadi – Central channel, balance, spiritual awakening, not directly linked to autonomic NS.

question: Nadi linked to Parasympathetic NS
description: Ida Nadi – Cooling, lunar, left side, parasympathetic functions (rest–digest). Pingala Nadi – Heating, solar, right side, sympathetic functions (fight–flight). Sushumna Nadi – Central channel, balance, spiritual awakening, not directly linked to autonomic NS.

question: Different layers of Susumna
description: Inside the Suṣumṇā Nadi, there are said to be three inner layers/channels: Vajra Nadi – the inner layer; Chitrini Nadi (also called Chitrā / Chitrini) – subtler luminous channel; Brahma Nadi – the innermost, through which Kundalini finally ascends

question: When Ida Nadi is activated, one should do
description: Ida Nadi → Lunar channel, left side, cooling, feminine, associated with manas (mind), intuition, planning, creativity. Pingala Nadi → Solar channel, right side, heating, masculine, associated with physical work, action, stamina. So when Ida Nadi is active → it’s the best time for mental work, creativity, thinking, planning, intellectual tasks.

question:
When Pingala Nadi is activated, one should do
activated, one should do
description: Pingala Nadi → Solar channel, right side, heating, masculine, dynamic, linked with sympathetic nervous system. It governs physical energy, vitality, action, digestion, and execution. So when Pingala is active, best suited for physical work, outdoor tasks, execution, and action-oriented activities

question: Breath alternates between Ida & Pingala every
description: According to Hatha Yoga & Swara Yoga texts, the flow of breath alternates between the left (Ida) and right (Pingala) nostrils roughly every 60–90 minutes in a healthy person. This is also supported by modern physiology → the nasal cycle averages 90 min (range 60–120 min).

question: Nadi extending from mouth to anus
description: This comes from the list of 72,000 nadis described in texts like Hatha Yoga Pradipika, Shiva Samhita, and Gheranda Samhita. Alambusa Nadi → Extends from mouth to anus (runs along the alimentary canal). Kausiki Nadi → Associated with the left ear. Gandhari Nadi → Associated with the left eye.

question: Nadi responsible for sight
description: This is from minor nadis descriptions in Gheranda Samhita and Hatha Yoga Pradipika. Hastijihva Nadi → Connected with the right eye. Gandhari Nadi → Connected with the left eye. Kausiki Nadi → Connected with the left ear.

question: Nadi associated with ejaculation
description: Chitra / Chitrini → Inside Sushumna, subtle luminous channel, linked to higher awakening, not ejaculation. Varuni → Associated with urinary system & genitals (excretion of urine). Kuhu → Nadi associated with the reproductive organs & responsible for ejaculation / seminal discharge.

question: Alabdha-Bhumikatva is
options: Failing to attain a firm ground
Failing to maintain a firm ground
description: This comes from obstacles in Yoga (Antarāyas) described in Patanjali Yoga Sutras (PYS 1.30–31). Alabdha-bhūmikatva (अलब्धभूमिकत्व) literally = failure (alabdha) to obtain (labh) the stage/ground (bhūmika). It means inability to attain the next stage of practice → failing to gain a firm footing in Yoga progress. Failing to maintain a firm ground → Anavasthitatva; Failing to have mental clarity → closer to Bhranti-darshana or distraction.
